childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1980-1992

The smell of a fresh box of Crayola 64s. The satisfying click of a View-Master reel. The weight of an Atari joystick in your hands, playing Pitfall until your thumb went numb. Your childhood had a texture that kids today will never know—everything was physical, chunky, built to survive being thrown across a room.

John Lennon was killed the year you were born. Your parents remember where they were when they heard. 'Who Shot J.R.?' was the question that summer—33 million people watched Dallas to find out. Pac-Man arrived in arcades, swallowing quarters. The world you entered was anxious, disco-hungover, and about to turn sharply to the right.

At two, you were watching Sesame Street when Big Bird was still learning, and Mr. Rogers was teaching you that you were special just the way you are. By four, you'd discovered He-Man, Thundercats, and G.I. Joe—cartoons that existed to sell action figures, though you didn't know that yet. You had strong opinions about whether He-Man or Lion-O would win in a fight. (It was Lion-O. Obviously.)

Your toys told the story of your decade. Cabbage Patch Kids (you probably waited in line). Transformers (more than meets the eye). My Little Pony, Care Bears, Pound Puppies. The Rubik's Cube that sat unsolved on your shelf. Speak & Spell with its creepy robot voice. Lite-Brite patterns that never looked like the box. The Easy-Bake Oven that produced hockey-puck brownies you ate anyway.

At six, your whole class watched the Challenger explode on a TV wheeled into the classroom. Christa McAuliffe was supposed to be an inspiration. Instead, you learned early that sometimes things go catastrophically wrong while adults stand there looking helpless. You remember the teachers crying. You remember not understanding why.

Friday nights meant Pizza Hut (the red cups, the personal pan pizzas from Book It!), or McDonald's (Happy Meal toys you collected obsessively), or if you were lucky, Showbiz Pizza with the animatronic band that was definitely going to come alive and murder everyone. You drank Capri Sun through those impossible straws. You ate Fruit Roll-Ups, Fun Dip, and Pop Rocks while someone warned you about exploding stomachs. You survived.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

Gen X. The forgotten middle child of American generations—too young to be Boomers, too old to be Millennials, too small to matter much to marketers. You're about 65 million people wedged between two massive demographic waves—76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials—that get all the attention. You learned early that nobody was coming to save you. This turned out to be useful training.

You were nine when the Berlin Wall fell. Your parents cried watching crowds with sledgehammers—for them, it was the end of an existential threat they'd lived under their entire lives. For you, it was confusing. The Cold War was supposed to last forever. That was the whole point of 'duck and cover' drills and The Day After nightmares. Then suddenly, history ended. Except it didn't.

Your generation spans 1965 to 1980—you're the tail end, the youngest, which means you share traits with both Gen X cynicism and Millennial optimism. You're a bridge generation before that term existed. You remember rotary phones but adapted to smartphones. You're analog by birth and digital by choice. Authority figures lie, institutions fail, trust is earned, not given.

The latchkey kid label is yours. Your parents were working, or divorcing, or both. You came home to an empty house and let yourself in with the key around your neck. You made your own snacks (Bagel Bites, Hot Pockets, whatever was microwaveable). You did your homework without supervision. You learned self-reliance through benign neglect, and it stuck.

Irony is your native language. You came of age during Reagan's 'Morning in America' while crack devastated cities and AIDS killed thousands. You watched the adults say one thing and do another. You responded by refusing to take anything too seriously. Sincerity was dangerous. Cynicism was armor. You still flinch a little when someone is earnest about something.

At {{AGE_AT_911}}, you were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Being the youngest Gen X means you got the cultural references (Reality Bites, Singles, Clerks) but also grew up with technology young enough to be fluent. You're the last people who remember life before the internet AND the first who adopted it naturally. This gives you a perspective that's increasingly rare—you know what was lost, and what was gained. You can still entertain yourself without a screen. That's a superpower now.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

The Empire Strikes Back came out the year you were born—'I am your father' wasn't spoiled on the internet because there was no internet. Ordinary People won Best Picture. Blondie's 'Call Me' topped the charts. These weren't your movies or your music, but they were in the air, absorbed through cultural osmosis, playing on cable throughout your childhood until you knew them by heart.

Your actual pop culture education started with MTV. It launched when you were one, and by the time you were five or six, music videos were your religion. Michael Jackson's 'Thriller'—you watched it through your fingers, terrified and fascinated. Prince in Purple Rain, Madonna in 'Like a Virgin,' Bruce Springsteen in 'Dancing in the Dark.' You learned that music was visual, performative, an event.

At six, Ferris Bueller taught you that life moves pretty fast—if you don't stop and look around, you might miss it. At seven, The Princess Bride gave you quotable lines for life. At eight, you were quoting Beetlejuice and probably traumatized by Large Marge in Pee-wee's Big Adventure. At nine, Batman got dark and serious and you were here for it.

Your cartoon education was serious business. G.I. Joe (knowing is half the battle), Transformers (robots in disguise), He-Man (by the power of Grayskull). Later: DuckTales, Chip 'n Dale Rescue Rangers, and the afternoon Disney block you raced home for. Saturday mornings were sacred—bowls of Lucky Charms or Fruity Pebbles, pajamas until noon, three hours of uninterrupted animation.

Middle school was hair metal. Bon Jovi's 'Livin' on a Prayer,' Def Leppard's 'Pour Some Sugar on Me,' Guns N' Roses' 'Welcome to the Jungle.' You had band t-shirts and strong opinions about guitar solos. Then grunge arrived and killed it all overnight. You were twelve when Nirvana's 'Nevermind' dropped, and suddenly everyone was embarrassed about their spandex. Kurt Cobain made sadness cool, and you were the perfect age to internalize it.

High school was the '90s alternative explosion: Pearl Jam, Soundgarden, Alice in Chains, Nine Inch Nails. You wore flannel ironically and then unironically. You saw Reality Bites and recognized yourself—overeducated, underemployed, trying to figure out what the point was. Winona Ryder was your spirit animal. Your college years were late-'90s chaos: third-wave ska, nu-metal, boy bands existing in parallel dimensions. By 1999, you had a fully formed musical identity that TRL couldn't touch.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

The beep of a Pac-Man machine is burned into your memory. The arcade was your church—rows of cabinets glowing in the dark, quarters lined up on screens to claim your place in line. Pac-Man, Donkey Kong, Space Invaders, Galaga. You were born the year Pac-Man arrived, and by the time you were old enough to hold a joystick, the golden age was in full swing.

At one, IBM released the first PC. At four, the Macintosh launched with that famous Super Bowl ad. By the time you were old enough to care, computers were transitioning from science fiction to household appliances. Your family might have had a Commodore 64, an Apple IIe, or nothing at all—home computers were still optional.

The video game crash of 1983 happened when you were three. The NES resurrection came when you were five. Super Mario Bros. was your real childhood—that first world, that first mushroom, that first flag pole. You argued about whether Mario or Sonic was better once the Genesis arrived, and you had Opinions with a capital O.

At fifteen, Netscape Navigator launched, and the internet stopped being just for nerds. You were in high school when email became a thing people actually used. Your first email address was probably something embarrassing on Hotmail or Juno. You learned HTML to make a GeoCities page with animated GIFs and a visitor counter that never climbed as high as you wanted.

AIM arrived during college—away messages crafted like poetry, buddy lists organized by social hierarchy, the door-opening sound when someone signed on. You learned to communicate in abbreviations your parents couldn't decode. You burned mix CDs with handwritten track lists. You downloaded songs on Napster, one three-minute track taking twenty minutes over your dorm's ethernet.

You graduated into the dot-com boom, watched it implode, then watched it rebuild. The iPhone came out when you were 27, after you'd already established adult habits. You adapted quickly but weren't defined by it. You're the last generation that can read a map, remember phone numbers, and be truly bored with nothing to scroll. These are superpowers now.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

The Iran hostage crisis cast a shadow over your first year—444 days of Americans held captive, yellow ribbons everywhere, nightly news countdowns that made your parents feel helpless.

Where were you when the Challenger exploded? You were six, probably in school, probably watching on a TV the teacher wheeled in because a schoolteacher was going to space. January 28, 1986. Seventy-three seconds after launch. You watched it happen live, and you watched the adults not know what to say. It was your first lesson in how quickly everything can go wrong.

The Cold War was the background radiation of your childhood—air raid drills, nuclear nightmares, the Soviet Union as permanent villain. Then you were nine, and the Berlin Wall fell. You watched crowds with sledgehammers and champagne, and suddenly the world your parents had prepared you for didn't exist anymore. At eleven, the Soviet Union collapsed entirely. The enemy vanished. New enemies would arrive soon enough.

You were eleven during the first Gulf War. CNN's green night-vision footage made war look like a video game—clean, precise, winnable. 'Operation Desert Storm' sounded like an action movie. America won in weeks. This shaped expectations that wouldn't survive contact with later conflicts.

At fifteen, the Oklahoma City bombing—domestic terrorism, Americans killing Americans, a federal building reduced to rubble. You were seventeen when Princess Diana died, and you watched 2.5 billion people mourn someone they'd never met. You were learning about collective grief, about how strangers become symbols.

Columbine happened when you were nineteen. April 20, 1999. You'd already graduated high school, but it still felt personal. Schools were supposed to be safe. The two kids with trench coats and automatic weapons changed that calculation forever. The lockdown drill era began.

At twenty, Y2K turned out to be nothing. The dot-com bubble burst. The 2000 election went to the Supreme Court over hanging chads. At {{AGE_AT_911}}, you were {{AGE_DESCRIPTOR_911}} when the towers fell on 9/11. Old enough to be a full adult. Old enough to enlist, if you wanted. Old enough to understand exactly how much the world was about to change. The wars that followed lasted your entire adult life. You've been at war, somewhere, your entire adulthood.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

Let's talk about the timing. You graduated college around 2002—after the dot-com bust, after 9/11, into an economy that had just remembered that gravity exists. The late-'90s optimism had evaporated. IPO millionaires were driving Uber before Uber existed. You entered the workforce when everyone was being told to be grateful for any job at all.

Your career path was supposed to look like your parents': get a job, work thirty years, get a pension, retire. Instead, you learned quickly that companies don't offer loyalty anymore—if they ever did. The old social contract—work hard, stay loyal, retire with a pension—was being shredded in real time. You watched the first wave of layoffs, learned the term 'restructuring,' understood viscerally that your employer would cut you the moment the spreadsheet demanded it. You adapted. You became a free agent because the alternative was pretending the old rules still applied.

Gen X invented job-hopping as survival strategy. Not because you wanted to leave—because staying meant watching your salary stagnate while new hires got better offers. Job security became an oxymoron. You learned to negotiate, to keep your resume updated, to never get too comfortable. Your Boomer bosses called you disloyal. You called it paying attention.

At {{AGE_AT_2008_CRISIS}}, the 2008 financial crisis arrived. The market dropped 40%. Established enough to survive, young enough to take a serious hit. You watched Millennials enter a destroyed job market while you held onto whatever you had. You became the bridge—the middle manager translating between executives who remembered the old economy and new hires who'd never seen one that worked.

Your career predates the ping-pong table era. You remember when offices had walls, when 'work-life balance' meant leaving at 6pm, when 'perks' meant health insurance and maybe a Christmas bonus. The performative fun of startup culture feels hollow to you because you remember when work was just work. You did it, you went home, you had a life.

COVID proved you could work from anywhere. Gen X had been doing it quietly for years—getting stuff done without performative presence. The pandemic just gave everyone else permission to join you. Now you're the experienced one, the institutional memory, the person who remembers why things are done a certain way. You didn't complain about it—you just did the work. That's your legacy: competence without fanfare.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

Remember when having a crush meant engineering 'accidental' encounters in the hallway? When getting someone's phone number required calling their house and talking to their parents first? When passing a note in class—folded into that complicated origami triangle—felt dangerously intimate?

You learned to communicate the old-fashioned way. Handwritten notes. Phone calls on the family's one landline, stretching the cord around the corner for privacy. Waiting by the phone. The agony of a busy signal. The heartbreak of calling and having their mom say they weren't home when you knew they were.

Your generation has a complicated relationship with marriage because you watched your parents' generation divorce at record rates. You saw the optimistic Boomer marriages implode in the '80s and '90s. You learned that 'forever' sometimes means 'until someone's happier elsewhere.' This made you either cautious about commitment or deliberately pragmatic about it.

You probably met your partner the old-fashioned way—at school, at work, through friends, at a bar. Dating apps arrived after most of you were already coupled up. You missed the swipe era. You're simultaneously grateful and curious. Your single friends have stories that sound exhausting. Your married friends have stability that looks increasingly valuable.

You're the bridge generation in relationships. You remember when meeting online was embarrassing, something you'd lie about. ('We met through friends.') Your younger siblings and cousins swipe through hundreds of profiles like it's normal. Your kids will probably date in the metaverse. You're just glad you locked someone down before it got weird.

Your friendships span time zones now. You've moved for work, for partners, for cheaper rent. You maintain relationships through group texts that have been active for twenty years, email chains where nobody needs to explain the references. You know how to be close to people who are far away. Gen X was doing long-distance friendship before social media made it easy.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

Three major economic crashes hit during your prime earning years. The dot-com bust when you were twenty. The 2008 financial crisis when you were twenty-eight—the market dropped 40%. COVID when you were forty. You've seen the floor fall out repeatedly. But you also saw the good times in between—the late-'90s boom, the mid-2000s recovery, the decade-long bull run before the pandemic. Your financial psychology is shaped by both: you know things can collapse, and you know they can also come back. Mortgage rates hit 18% in the early '80s—you inherited your parents' financial anxiety.

You probably bought a house. Maybe not your dream house, maybe not in your dream city, but homeownership was still achievable when you came of age. The median home price when you were twenty-five was around $200,000. It's over $400,000 now. You got in before the door slammed shut. This isn't virtue—it's timing.

You have 401(k)s and the vague hope that Social Security won't collapse before you're seventy. They bought houses on two years' salary. You bought on four. Your kids will need ten.

Your financial strategy is quiet accumulation. You max out your 401(k), you have an emergency fund, you don't talk about money because that's gauche. You learned from watching your parents—the credit card debt, the keeping-up-with-Joneses spending, the financial chaos of their divorces. You've been careful. Maybe too careful. You've missed some upside by being risk-averse.

You watch younger generations get blamed for not buying houses they can't afford, for not saving money they don't have. You know the game changed. Housing tripled while wages crawled. The avocado toast discourse is insulting—nobody's budgeting their way into a $500,000 starter home. You got lucky on timing. Anyone who pretends otherwise is either lying or not paying attention.

Retirement is a real possibility for you, which puts you ahead of most Millennials and Gen Z. But you're planning to work longer than your parents did, just in case. The safety net is fraying. You act accordingly—cautious, practical, always with one eye on the exit.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest weakness is the shrug. Gen X's signature move is not caring—'whatever' as philosophy. It works great as armor, poorly as a strategy for change. You've gotten so good at expecting nothing that you sometimes accept less than you deserve. That cynical detachment that protected you from disappointment? It also prevents you from fighting for something better.

You're skeptical of collective action because you've seen it fail. You watched the idealism of the '60s curdle into the greed of the '80s. You don't trust movements, institutions, or promises of change. This makes you resistant to manipulation—nobody's selling you utopia. But it also makes you resistant to genuine progress. Sometimes things actually can get better, if enough people push.

Your independence is sometimes just isolation in disguise. You learned to take care of yourself because nobody else would, and you've internalized that so deeply that asking for help feels like weakness. It's not. It's how communities work. The rugged individualism that got you through latchkey afternoons isn't always the right tool for adult problems.

You've adapted so well to broken systems that you've forgotten they're broken. Corporate dysfunction, political gridlock, economic precarity—you've normalized all of it. You cope so effectively that you've stopped questioning whether coping should be necessary. The water you swim in is toxic, and you've stopped tasting it.

Your ironic distance protects you but also disconnects you. Everything's a joke. Nothing's worth getting too invested in. This shields you from disappointment but also from joy. Somewhere along the way, earnestness became embarrassing. You hedge everything with self-deprecation because sincerity feels dangerous. You're missing out.

And maybe the deepest blind spot: you think younger generations are soft because they complain. But complaining is how change happens. Your stoicism isn't virtue—it's resignation dressed up as toughness. Sometimes the appropriate response to injustice is outrage, not a shrug and a sarcastic comment. The world doesn't improve through ironic detachment.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (2000-2010): You started your career in the shadow of the dot-com bust and 9/11. The late-'90s irrational exuberance had crashed back to earth. You job-hopped more than your parents approved of, chasing opportunities in an uncertain economy. Some of you bought houses before 2008, which was either brilliant or catastrophic depending on timing and location. You watched the housing market collapse and learned that 'safe investments' was an oxymoron. By the end of the decade, you'd survived two major economic disruptions and developed the wariness that would define your financial life.

Your 30s (2010-2020): This was your establishment decade. The economy recovered, mostly. You built careers, families, equity. You became the responsible adults you swore you'd never become—worrying about school districts and retirement accounts and whether your parents were okay living alone. You had kids (maybe), got promoted (probably), and started noticing that the new college grads seemed very young. The distance between you and the generations on either side of you widened into a gulf.

Your 40s (2020-2030): You're in this decade now. COVID hit when you were forty, disrupting everything you'd carefully constructed. Remote work became permanent for many of you. Your kids are teenagers or approaching it, needing less supervision and more wisdom. Your parents are aging, needing more attention. You're sandwiched—responsible for generations on either side while trying to navigate your own peak-career complexity. You're tired in a way that doesn't go away with a good night's sleep.

Your 50s (2030-2040): Your kids will launch (hopefully). Your parents may need serious care or may be gone. You'll be thinking concretely about retirement—not as abstraction but as math problem. When can you afford to stop? Where will you live? What will you do with yourself? The youngest workers won't understand your references to Nirvana or the Challenger or life before smartphones. You'll be the institutional memory, the person who remembers how things used to work.

Your 60s and beyond (2040+): Retirement, if the numbers work. You'll be 65 in 2045, eligible for whatever Social Security still exists. You'll have lived through the entire digital revolution—from Pac-Man to whatever comes next. Climate change will have reshaped where people can live. The world will be unrecognizable in ways you can't predict. And you'll tell younger people what it was like before the internet was everywhere, before phones were in every pocket. They won't believe you. It'll sound like medieval history.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

{{BIRTH_YEAR_COHORT}} people were born in the US the same year as you. You're part of the 65 million Americans classified as Gen X—the smallest generation between 76 million Boomers and 72 million Millennials, the demographic valley between two peaks. You're the middle child of American generations. You've been overlooked your entire life. You're used to it.

Compared to Baby Boomers (born 1946-1964): They got the economy when it worked. Post-war expansion, manufacturing jobs that paid middle-class wages, houses that cost two years' salary. They got pensions. They got affordable college. When Boomers were your age, they controlled about 25% of national wealth. Gen X controls 14%. The gap isn't about work ethic—it's about arriving at different points in the same rigged game. They pulled up the ladder behind them. You're the one who noticed.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996): You're only a year or two apart from the oldest Millennials, but the generational line puts you in different categories. You entered the workforce before the Great Recession; they entered during. You bought houses when they were merely expensive; they're trying to buy when they're absurd. You're slightly more cynical, slightly less burdened by debt, slightly more likely to own property. This isn't virtue—it's timing. The game changed between you.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012): You're from different planets. They've never known a world without smartphones, social media, or school shooter drills. You remember all three arriving. They're digital natives; you're digital immigrants who became fluent. You have nostalgia for a world they can't imagine. They have nihilism about a future you helped create. Neither of you can afford as much as Boomers could.

Your life expectancy is around 76-78 years. You're healthier than previous generations in some ways (less smoking, more fitness awareness) and less healthy in others (obesity, deaths of despair, the mental health toll of living through endless 'unprecedented' events). You normalized therapy, which is genuinely good, even if you still feel weird about going.

You're the forgotten middle child of American generations—overlooked, independent, skeptical, resilient. You got the cultural touchstones (Reality Bites, grunge, the end of the Cold War) but not the numbers to be a market force. You'll never be the main character in generational discourse. That's fine. You don't need the attention. You just keep showing up, doing the work, handling whatever comes next. It's what you've always done.

year_events: John Lennon shot outside the Dakota
